intro: Struthanthus oblongus, commonly known as the woolly sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and showy yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late summer. It typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, demonstrating a high degree of drought tolerance. Its unique appearance and adaptability make it an interesting subject for botanical study and ecological research.
